I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to  the  Democratic  Republic  of  Timor-Leste  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  Road  Network 
Upgrading Sector Project.1 
 
2. 
The proposed additional financing will support the scaling up of the project through the 
addition  of  97  kilometers  (km)  of  national  roads  to  the  81  km  to  be  upgraded  and  climate 
proofed under the current project scope.2 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The  government  adopted  a  strategic  development  plan  (SDP)  for  2011–2030  in  2011 
that  aims  to  sustain  economic  growth,  fast-track  economic  development,  and  modernize  and 
diversify  the  economy  by  providing  the  country  with  high-quality  infrastructure.3 The  SDP  is 
based  on  the  three  pillars  of  developing  social  capital,  infrastructure,  and  the  economy.  It 
prioritizes  public  investments  in  2011–2015  that  will  create  the  conditions  to  attract  private 
investment and support private sector growth. This includes investments in roads, since a safe 
and  efficient  transport  system  is  essential  to  progress  in  all  three  of  the  SDP’s  priority  areas. 
During  2011–2017,  the  SDP  and  current  government  operational  plans  concentrate  on 
upgrading  roads  to  achieve  quick  returns  and  transformational  changes  needed  for  economic 
progress, inclusive development, and social stability. 
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  country  partnership  strategy  for  Timor-Leste  for 
4. 
2011–2015 has carried on ADB’s previous concentration on the development and management 
of infrastructure, and on complementary activities that support the private sector as a driver of 
change.4 The  strategy  aims  to  help  the  country  make  services  more  available  outside  of  the 
capital  city  of  Dili  by  improving  transport  connectivity  to  support  growth  in  the  rural  economy. 
This  is  expected  to  reduce  poverty  by  giving  the  poor  access  to  markets  and  basic  public 
services.  It  will  also  help  spread  economic  activity  and  the  benefits  of  the  country’s  petroleum 
wealth more broadly to areas beyond the capital.  
 
5. 
The  road  network  in  Timor-Leste  had  deteriorated  during  a  25-year  conflict  that 
preceded independence in 2002 due to a lack of investment in maintenance, rehabilitation, and 
upgrades. This deterioration continued during 2002–2011 when the efforts made to rehabilitate 
the  network  were  inadequate.  Poor  road  conditions  were  constraining  the  country’s  efforts  to 
develop. 5  In  2011,  however,  the  SDP  recognized  that  more  substantial  investments  were 
needed in road rehabilitation and upgrades if the network was to be made sustainable.

5   A condition survey conducted in 2012 with the support of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) found 
that 76% of a 950-kilometer (km) sample of the overall 1,428 km national road network was in fair condition and in 
need of intervention in the near future. About 23% was determined to be in poor condition and requiring immediate 
attention.  

 Led by ADB, Timor-Leste’s development partners have responded to the challenge in a 
6. 
substantial,  coordinated  way.  They  include  the  Government  of  Australia,  the  European  Union, 
the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (JICA),  and  the World  Bank.  ADB  has  supported 
the Road Network Development Sector Project, the Road Network Upgrading Project, and the 
Road  Network  Upgrading  Sector  Project.6 Together  with  projects  now  being  implemented  with 
the support of JICA and the World Bank, these operations will upgrade about 360 km or 25% of 
the  national  road  network  by  the  end  of  2018  (map).7 The  Government  of  Australia  and  the 
European  Union  have  focused  their  complementary  activities  on  the  district  and  rural  road 
network  and  have  emphasized  support  for  road  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  through  the 
development  of  small-scale  contractors  and  community  involvement.  ADB’s  projects  are  on 
track to upgrade 190 km of national road by 2018. About 100 km of these roads are expected to 
be  mostly  completed  by  the  end  of  2015.  Including  the  expanded  scope  of  the  overall  Road 
Network Upgrading Sector Project to be funded under the proposed additional financing, these 
ADB activities and those under way with assistance from other development partners will have 
upgraded at least 570 km or 40% of the country’s national road network when completed.  
 
The  Ministry  of  Public  Works,  Transport  and  Communication  (MPWTC)  lacks  the  full 
7. 
staff  and  institutional  capacity  needed  to  properly  implement  capital  works  or  maintain  road 
assets.  ADB-financed  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  supporting  scholarships  for  its  professional 
staff  and  a  program  to  build  the  necessary  technical  knowledge.  The  TA  is  also  helping  to 
formulate  a  capacity  development  framework  and  a  strategic  development  plan  for  the 
MPWTC.8 A  project  management  unit  (PMU)  embedded  in  the  MPWTC  and  responsible  for 
managing  ADB,  JICA,  and World  Bank  programs  has  considerable  experience  in  dealing  with 
the  requirements  of  development  partners  and  other  government  agencies.  To  date,  the  PMU 
has  successfully  coordinated  the  activities  of  the  development  partners  and  has  ensured  that 
the  projects  they  support  have  applied  consistent  technical  standards  and  safeguards.  It  has 
also been successful in managing the interface with government agencies whose cooperation is 
necessary for smooth implementation of individual projects. 
 
8. 
The MPWTC continues to develop systems for routine maintenance of national roads. It 
plans  to  introduce  performance-based  maintenance  (PBM)  contracts  for  all  upgraded  roads. 
However,  civil  works  contracts  for  development  partner-financed  roads  require  contractors  to 
carry  out  routine  maintenance  for  2  years  after  the  defects  notification  period. 9 This  ensures 
that the immediate and short-term maintenance needs on these upgraded roads are met. Two 
PBM contracts being piloted under ADB’s Road Network Development Project have introduced 
the  concept  to  local  contractors,  consultants,  and  ministry  personnel.  The  experience  to  be 
gleaned  while  overseeing  the  2-year  contractor  maintenance  periods  will  also  help  build 
MPWTC capacity to implement network wide PBM. ADB is continuing to work closely with the 
ministry  to  help  it  plan,  budget,  procure,  and  implement  maintenance  operations.  An 
international  road  maintenance  specialist  financed  by  ADB  is  currently  helping  the  MPWTC’s 
newly created maintenance division to prepare a detailed maintenance plan for 2016.10

 The  loans  for  the  current  project  became  effective  3  March  2014.  Progress  toward  the 
9. 
intended  outputs  has  been  satisfactory,  and  the  outcome  is  expected  to  be  achieved.  The 
contract packages for civil  works and consultant services have been procured, and civil  works 
have started. No cost overrun is foreseen, although the project is about 14% behind schedule 
due  mostly  to  longer-than-anticipated  times  for  procurement,  contract  awards,  and  contractor 
mobilization.  The  government  has  streamlined  the  related  procedures.  Contracts  are  now 
deemed  to  be  endorsed  if  the  government’s  Court  of  Accounts  makes  no  objection  within  30 
days  of  its  submission  for  approval,  facilitating  the  process. 11  The  National  Procurement 
Commission  will  use  a  single-stage,  one-envelope  procedure  for  future  civil  works  contracts 
instead of the single-stage, two-envelope procedure, potentially shortening the awards process 
by  up  to  3  months.  These  measures  will  prevent  delays  similar  to  those  faced  by  the  current 
project to be repeated in the overall scaled-up project.  
 
10. 
Compliance  during the  current  project  with  ADB and government  safeguards  has  been 
satisfactory. While the core subproject has only a minimal resettlement impact, the government 
has budgeted the funds needed to compensate affected persons. 
 
11. 
The  current  project  meets  ADB’s  criteria  for  a  project  progressing  well  except  it  is  not 
rated “on track” because of a shortfall in actual disbursements against projections.12 Civil works 
are on schedule but payments to contractors, and hence disbursements, are delayed due to an 
administrative  review  of  tax  liabilities  on  a  separate  contract  that  is  not  financed  by  ADB,  and 
delays in incorporating the company as a local business.13 Payment delays have not materially 
impacted  implementation. 14 The  project  is  eligible  for  additional  financing  because  (i)  it  will 
remain technically feasible, economically viable, and financially sound, and each new subproject 
will  be  required to meet the  subproject  eligibility  criteria; (ii)  the  subprojects  are  accorded  high 
priority  by  the  government;  (iii)  the  subprojects  are  consistent  with  the  project’s  development 
objectives; and (iv) the overall project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy. 
 
Additional financing  of the  current  project  is the most  efficient  way for  ADB  to maintain 
12. 
the momentum of its program of support for achieving the government’s objectives in the road 
transport sector. Three new subprojects are proposed under the additional financing to upgrade 
97 km of national road. These will ensure the completion of the north coast road by the end of 
2019 (map). After this scaling up and the completion of all of its projects, ADB will have helped 
upgrade 20% (285 km) of the national road network and made a significant impact on improving 
connectivity across the country. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

13. 
The impact of the project will be increased and more efficient movement of people and 
goods. The  outcome  will  be  a  more  reliable  and safer road  network. The  impact  and  outcome 
are  unchanged  from  the  current  project,  although  the  project’s  expanded  road  improvement 
output will directly benefit a greater number of people.

C. 

Outputs 

 Although the current project’s four outputs will remain essentially the same in the overall 

14. 
project with the additional financing, scope and targets or timelines will change for two of them. 
 
15. 
Output  1:  National  roads  upgraded  and  climate  proofed.  An  additional  97  km  of 
national roads will be strengthened with the additional financing. The existing sealed pavements 
of  the  Baucau–Lautem,  Maubara–Karimbala,  and  Atabae–Mota  Ain  sections  will  be  widened 
from  less  than  4.5  meters  to  6  meters  with  the  provision  of  asphalt  surfacing.  Vulnerability  to 
damage from severe rainfall, sea level rise, and other potential effects of climate change will be 
reduced  through  engineering  countermeasures.  These  will  include  drainage  structures  of 
suitable sizes, the raising of road levels in flood-prone areas, and the use of bioengineering to 
promote  slope  stability.  This  will  be  in  addition  to  the  similar  work  being  undertaken  by  the 
current  project  on  81  km  of  national  roads.  Average  roughness  on  all  178  km  of  the  overall 
project’s roads will be reduced to the same level.  

 
Output  2:  Detailed  designs  for  future  priority  road  links  prepared.  Detailed 
16. 
engineering design and social and environmental due diligence will be prepared for about 169 
km of national roads.  

 
Output 3: Performance-based road maintenance expanded. Civil works contracts for 
17. 
both  the  original  and  additional  project’s  roads  will  provide  for  a  2-year  maintenance  period 
starting after the defects notification period during which the contractor will undertake PBM. On-
the-job training will be delivered by the contract supervisor. 
 
18. 
Output  4:  Awareness  raised  of  road  safety  and  transport-related  social  issues. 
Road  safety  awareness  will  be  increased  by  extending  the  community-based  road  safety 
awareness  program,  including  an  education  program  for  schools,  drivers,  road  users  and  the 
community,  and  implementing  an  HIV/AIDS  prevention  program to  all  communities  along  both 
the original and the additional project’s roads.

The  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $53,000,000  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources (OCR) to help finance the project. The OCR loan will have a 25-year term, including a 
grace  period  of  5  years,  an  annual  interest rate determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London

works,  taxes  and  duties,  late  payment  charges  imposed  by  suppliers  and  contractors,  bank 
charges,  local  transport  costs,  insurance  costs,  and  interest  and  commitment  charges  during 
construction on the OCR loan.16   
 
The  government  has  also  requested  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to 
21. 
SDR16,574,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the project. The loan will 
have  a  25-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years,  an  interest  rate  of  2%  per  annum 
during the grace period and thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

23. 
The PMU established in the MPWTC is responsible for the management of the original 
project and will manage the additional project outputs (para. 7). The PMU is headed by a project 
manager  and  has  a  full-time  professional  staff,  including  a  chief  technical  advisor,  a  road 
construction advisor, a road maintenance engineer, and a financial administrator. The PMU has 
been strengthened steadily as its portfolio responsibilities have grown. International and national 
specialists provide a full-time safeguards unit within the PMU. 
 
Further  additional  financing,  including  cofinancing  to  meet  a  potential  financing  gap  for 
24. 
implementing  additional  candidate  subprojects,  may  be  considered  in  the  future  if  the  project 
performs well.

25.

the  arrangements  are  essentially  unchanged  from  the  current  project.  The  arrangements  and 
changes are described in detail in the project administration manual (PAM).18

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

 
A. 

Technical  

26. 
The pavements of the roads to be upgraded will be reconstructed and will allow for faster 
travel and substantially reduced vehicle operating costs. Climate resilience will be emphasized 
in  subproject  engineering  designs.  Vulnerability  to  damage from  severe  rainfall, sea  level  rise, 
and  other  potential  effects  of  climate  change  will  be  reduced 
through  engineering 
countermeasures,  including  providing  suitably-sized  drainage  structures,  raising  road  levels  in 
flood-prone areas, and using bioengineering to promote slope stability. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

Subprojects financed by ADB will be required to meet the subproject selection criteria.19 
27. 
Economic  analysis  has  been  undertaken  for  each  of  the  three  new  subprojects  in  the  overall 
project  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  guidelines,  and  each  was  found  to  meet  the  subproject 
selection  criteria  (footnote  18). 20   The  analysis  estimated  economic  internal  rates  of  return  of 
14.1%  for  the  Maubara–Karimbala  and  Atabae–Mota  Ain  roads  combined  and  10.7%  for  the 
Baucau–Lautem section. An engineering assessment has found that it costs significantly less to 
maintain  an  upgraded  road  in  Timor-Leste  than  it  does  to  maintain  unimproved  roads.  Timor-
Leste has a sovereign wealth fund derived from petroleum revenue that has accumulated since 
2005  and  currently  stands  at  about  $16  billion.  Provided  that  the  fund  is  prudently  managed, 
Timor-Leste  will  remain  able  to  allocate  funds  for  maintenance  of  road  transport  assets, 
including those created under the project. 
 
C. 

Governance 

28. 
The  governance  environment  has  not  changed  since  it  was  assessed  for  the  current 
project.  The  public  financial  management  system  is  heavily  centralized.  Numerous  controls 
result  in  bottlenecks  that  slow  payment  processes  and  weaken  budget  implementation.  The 
government has promoted decentralization of noncore financial management functions from the 
Ministry of Finance to line ministries as capacity in these agencies has improved. However, the 
system for payments still involves reviews of payment certificates provided by the PMU and the 
MPWTC by several agencies. 
 
29. 
The government  created  the  National  Procurement  Commission  in  2011. With  the  help 
of the PMU, the commission has administered the bidding processes for ADB-financed projects 

                                                 
19  Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
20  ADB. 1997. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila. 

7 

 

 8 

 

during  2012–2014  in  a  satisfactory  way  and  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  guidelines.  However, 
procurement still needs to be made more transparent and efficient, and a balance between risk 
and  accountability  for  projects  without  development  partner  oversight  has  not  yet  been 
achieved. 
 
30. 
The executing agency, the Council for the Administration of the Infrastructure Fund, was 
established in 2011 to oversee the use of the state fund for financing infrastructure.21 The Civil 
Service  Act  (2004)  provides  standards,  principles,  definitions,  and  guidelines  for  civil  service 
administration; a code of ethics for civil servants; and an administrative disciplinary mechanism. 
A  law  creating  a  new  anticorruption  commission  became  effective  in  2009,  and  the  first 
anticorruption  commissioner  was  appointed  in  2010.  However,  the  commission  needs  more 
resources.  
 
31. 
To mitigate the governance risks, the MPWTC has implemented several ADB-supported 
infrastructure  projects  through  its  PMU  (footnote  7).  This  PMU  will  oversee  execution  of  the 
expanded project scope under the additional financing. The PMU has a financial administrator 
with  considerable  experience  with  ADB-financed  projects.  Based  on  ADB’s  previous  project 
experience, the PMU has the capacity to manage the project. 
 
32. 
ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  the 
government  and  the  executing  agency.  Specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 17). 

 
Poverty and Social 

D. 

33. 
The  primary  beneficiaries  of  the  project  will  be  (i)  vehicle  drivers  and  passengers,  
nonmotorized transport users, and all others using the roads to be upgraded; (ii) households in 
communities that sell cash crops and other agricultural produce; (iii) providers of passenger and 
goods  transport  services  and  commercial  truck  drivers;  and (iv)  small  businesses  and traders, 
including  vendors  at  local  markets,  trade  store  owners,  coffee  and  other  produce  buyers,  and 
small-  and  medium-sized  enterprises  in  the  district  capitals  and  towns.  Key  social  service 
providers,  such  as  those  in  the  education  and  health  sectors,  will  also  benefit  from  the  road 
upgrades. 
 
34. 
The  women  of  Timor-Leste  have  generally  been  excluded  from  infrastructure-related 
jobs  and  decision  making  related  to  infrastructure  development.  The  project  aims  to  redress 
this.  Classified  by  ADB  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming,  the  project  will  support  the 
empowerment  of  women  and  ensure that they  are given  some  of the  jobs  the  subprojects  will 
generate. 22  The  project  will  (i) incorporate  women’s  views  in  the  project  design;  (ii)  raise 
awareness of gender and transport security and HIV/AIDS; (iii) have a quota for the employment 
of women in the construction work, favoring unemployed widows, female heads of households, 
and  other  vulnerable  groups;  and  (iv)  have  a  quota  for  the  involvement  by  women  in 
bioengineering and maintenance works. 
 
E. 

Safeguards 

35. 
Involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples.  The  project  has  been  classified 
category  B  for  resettlement  and  category  C  for  indigenous  peoples.  The  road  improvement

 work  is  expected  to  be  mostly  within  the  existing  road  corridor,  but  it  will  require  some 
resettlement from small areas of land, some houses and shops, and roadside stalls and kiosks. 
A resettlement framework has been prepared, providing guidelines on screening, assessment, 
and the preparation of resettlement plans for road subprojects. The resettlement plan has been 
prepared and disclosed for the subproject under the current project. Draft resettlement plans for 
the additional subprojects have been prepared in accordance with the resettlement framework 
and will be cleared by ADB prior to its approval of each subproject. They will then be disclosed 
on  the  government’s  and  ADB’s  websites.  The  MPWTC  will  publicly  disclose  each  draft 
resettlement plan and disseminate relevant information in local languages in subproject areas. 
 
36.  
The  MPWTC  will  finalize  the  resettlement  plan  for  each  subproject  after  the  detailed 
design  is  prepared  and  ensure  that  affected  persons  receive  compensation  in  line  with  the 
resettlement  framework.  Each  resettlement  plan  will  comply  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) and Timor-Leste laws and be cleared by ADB. The MPWTC will (i) appoint a 
focal  person  for  land  issues;  (ii)  set  up  an  environmental  and  social  unit  within  the  PMU, 
including  social  safeguard  specialists;  (iii)  coordinate  with  the  Department  of  Land,  Property, 
and  Cadastral  Services,  as  well  as  other  relevant  agencies;  and  (iv)  set  up  committees  to 
implement resettlement activities. MPWTC’s social safeguard capacity will be strengthened by 
providing resettlement specialists for 30 person-months and by conducting training. 
 
Environment.  The  project  is  classified  as  category  B  for  the  environment.  An 
37. 
environmental assessment and review framework has been prepared to ensure that the project 
will  comply  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  and  Timor-Leste  laws.  An  initial 
environmental  examination  (IEE)  was  prepared  for  the  current  project  based  on  the  detailed 
design.  This  was  disclosed,  along  with  the  environmental  framework,  on  the  government  and 
ADB  websites.  IEEs  for  each  additional  subproject  under  additional  financing  have  also  been 
prepared.  They  will  be  updated  based  on  the  detailed  designs  and  cleared  by  ADB.  The 
environmental  impacts  of  road  upgrading  works  during  construction  and  operation  have  been 
assessed and can be mitigated to acceptable levels.  
 
38. 
The  environmental management  plan  (EMP) from the  updated IEE for  each  subproject 
will  be  incorporated  in  civil  works  contracts.  The  EMP  will  guide  the  PMU,  supervision 
consultants,  and  contractors  in  managing,  monitoring,  and  reporting  environmental  impact 
mitigation and compliance. Civil works will not start until (i) the contractor has received training 
on  environmental  management  and  has  submitted  the  site-specific  EMP;  (ii)  the  site-specific 
EMP has been reviewed and cleared by the PMU, the supervision consultant, and ADB; and (iii) 
an environmental license has been obtained from the National Directorate for Environment. The 
environmental  management  capacity  of  the  Directorate  of  Roads,  Bridges,  and  Flood  Control 
and the PMU will be strengthened by environment specialists who will provide training.
